comments.html:
Very nice response. When I read the original article I was scratching my head as well. I guess the original author chose a wrong word - lossy.
Maybe his intention was to describe the fact that almost any normal TCP stream has certain amount of drops and retransmisions. We all have been on many troubleshooting calls, trying to explain this little fact to everybody...


P.s. The picture that describes the throughput is also weird, every oscilation should be smaller and smaller...
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html:
It is a pretty poorly written article. i rarely see loss on a telnet or ssh sessions (not running a vpn or file transfer inside), but since most people just look at tcp sessions running large web downloads or file transfers, they see congestion caused loss as the norm i guess.

The title of the post seems like it would be right at home in the "National Inquirer", which is a gossip rag here in the US.
comments.name: DuaneO

comments.html: And just for clarity, i did NOT mean your article, I meant the one that you are responding too above.
comments.name: DuaneO

comments.html: Yeah, it's poorly worded. "TCP is designed to operate on a lossy network, and uses loss as a signal to slow down" might be better.
comments.name: James Harr

comments.html: Yeah, it's poorly worded. "TCP is designed to operate on a lossy network, and uses loss as a signal to slow down" might be better.

comments.html: I thought the last part - that "nobody cares" - was the biggest howler of all.  What rock has the author been hiding under?
